articles.title: Oldest cave painting of red claw hand could rewrite human creativity timeline
articles.summary: A stencilled outline of a hand found on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi is the world's oldest known cave painting, researchers say.
articles.content:
Oldest cave painting of red claw hand could rewrite human creativity timeline

13 hours ago Share Save Pallab Ghosh Science Correspondent Share Save

A stencilled outline of a hand found on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi is the world's oldest known cave painting, researchers say. It shows a red outline of a hand whose fingers were reworked, researchers say, to create a claw-like motif which indicates an early leap in symbolic imagination. The painting has been dated to at least 67,800 years ago – around 1,100 years before the previous record, a controversial hand stencil in Spain. The find also strengthens the argument that our species, Homo sapiens, had reached the wider Australia–New Guinea landmass, known as Sahul, by around 15,000 years earlier than some researchers argue.

Over the past decade, a series of discoveries on Sulawesi has overturned the old idea that art and abstract thinking in our species burst suddenly into life in Ice Age Europe and spread from there. Cave art is seen as a key marker of when humans began to think in truly abstract, symbolic ways – the kind of imagination that underpins language, religion and science. Early paintings and engravings show people not just reacting to the world, but representing it, sharing stories and identities in a way no other species is known to have done. Professor Adam Brumm of Griffiths University in Australia, who co-led the project, told BBC News, that the latest discovery, published in the journal Nature, adds to the emerging view that there was no awakening for humanity in Europe. Instead, creativity was innate to our species, the evidence for which stretches back to Africa, where we evolved. "When I went to university in the mid to late 90s, that's what we were taught – the creative explosion in humans occurred in a small part of Europe. But now we're seeing traits of modern human behaviour, including narrative art in Indonesia, which makes that Eurocentric argument very hard to sustain". The oldest Spanish cave art is a red hand stencil in Maltravieso cave in Western Spain, dated to be at least 66,700 years old - though this is controversial and some experts don't think it to be that old.

In 2014, hand stencils and animal figures dating back at least 40,000 years were found in Sulawesi, followed by a hunting scene that is at least 44,000 year old, and then a narrative pig and human painting dated to at least 51,200 years ago. Each step pushed sophisticated image making further back in time, according to Professor Maxime Aubert of Griffiths University. "We started with minimum ages of at least 40,000 years, the same time as in Europe, but by getting closer to the pigment we've pushed the rock art in Sulawesi back by at least another 28,000 years". The latest discovery is from a limestone cave called Liang Metanduno on Muna, a small island off south eastern Sulawesi. It has been spray-painted: an ancient graffiti artist pressed their hand flat against the cave wall, then blew or spat a mouthful of pigment around it so that, when they pulled the hand away, a negative outline was left behind on the rock. One fragmentary hand stencil there is overlain by thin mineral crusts that, when analysed, was found to have a minimum age of 67,800 years, making it the oldest reliably dated cave art anywhere in the world. Crucially, the artist did more than simply spray pigment around a hand pressed to the wall, the researchers say.

Ahdi Agus Oktaviana More recent elongated hand stencils found elsewhere in Suluwesi shows how prevalent the red claw image was among these ancient artists.

After the original stencil was made, the outlines of the fingers were carefully altered – narrowed and elongated to make it look more claw-like; a creative transformation that Brumm argues is "a very us thing to do". He notes that there was no evidence of that experimentation in any of the art produced by our sister species, Neanderthals, in their cave paintings in Spain around 64,000 years ago. Even that is hotly contested because some researchers question the dating method. Until this latest discovery on Muna, all the paintings in Sulawesi had come from the Maros Pangkep karst in the island's south west. The fact that this much older stencil turns up on the opposite side of Sulawesi, on a separate satellite island, suggests that making images on cave walls was not a local experiment but deeply embedded in the cultures that spread across the region. Brumm says years of fieldwork by Indonesian colleagues have revealed "hundreds of new rock art sites" across remote areas, with some caves used repeatedly over tens of thousands of years. At Liang Metanduno, other, much younger paintings on the same panel – some produced as late as about 20,000 years ago – show that this single cave was a focus for artistic activity stretching over at least 35,000 years.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of the world's oldest known cave painting in Indonesia significantly revises our understanding of early human creativity and symbolic thinking, showing that such traits were widespread and innate rather than Eurocentric. This finding has broad implications for anthropology and human history, revealing early symbolic imagination and cultural complexity over 67,000 years ago, with substantial evidence and context provided.
articles.personality_title: World's oldest cave painting found in Indonesia changes history of human creativity
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For a long time, scientists believed that early humans only started making art and thinking in symbols in Europe during the Ice Age. Cave paintings are important because they show when humans began to imagine and share ideas in a new way.

**What happened** – Researchers found the oldest known cave painting on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi. It is a red stencil of a hand with fingers shaped like claws. This painting is at least 67,800 years old, making it older than the previous oldest hand stencil found in Spain by about 1,100 years. The painting was made by pressing a hand against the cave wall and spraying pigment around it, then changing the finger shapes to look like claws.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that early humans were creative and used symbols far earlier than thought, and not just in Europe. It suggests that humans had spread to nearby regions like Australia and New Guinea much earlier than some experts believed. The claw-shaped hand also shows a new level of imagination because it was a deliberate change to the hand’s shape, which is not seen in Neanderthal art.

**What's next step** – Scientists will keep exploring caves in Indonesia and nearby areas, where hundreds of new rock art sites have already been found. These discoveries could reveal even more about how early humans used art to communicate and express ideas over tens of thousands of years.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The oldest cave painting found in Indonesia proves early humans were creating symbolic art and thinking creatively much earlier and in more places than previously believed.
articles.personality_title_fr: La plus ancienne peinture rupestre découverte en Indonésie réécrit l'histoire de la créativité humaine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Pendant longtemps, les scientifiques ont pensé que les premiers humains ont commencé à créer de l'art et à penser en symboles en Europe pendant l'ère glaciaire. Les peintures rupestres sont importantes car elles montrent quand les humains ont commencé à imaginer et à partager des idées d'une nouvelle façon.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont découvert la plus ancienne peinture rupestre connue sur l'île indonésienne de Sulawesi. Il s'agit d'un pochoir rouge d'une main avec des doigts en forme de griffes. Cette peinture a au moins 67 800 ans, ce qui la rend plus vieille d'environ 1 100 ans que la plus ancienne main pochoirée trouvée en Espagne. La peinture a été réalisée en pressant une main contre la paroi de la grotte et en projetant du pigment autour, puis en modifiant délibérément la forme des doigts.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les premiers humains étaient créatifs et utilisaient des symboles bien plus tôt que ce que l'on pensait, et pas seulement en Europe. Elle suggère aussi que les humains s'étaient répandus dans des régions proches comme l'Australie et la Nouvelle-Guinée bien plus tôt que certains experts ne le croyaient. La main en forme de griffe montre un nouveau niveau d'imagination car c'était un changement volontaire de la forme des doigts, ce que l'on ne voit pas dans l'art des Néandertaliens.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à explorer les grottes en Indonésie et dans les régions voisines, où des centaines de nouveaux sites d'art rupestre ont déjà été découverts. Ces découvertes pourraient révéler encore plus sur la façon dont les premiers humains utilisaient l'art pour communiquer et exprimer des idées sur des dizaines de milliers d'années.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La plus ancienne peinture rupestre trouvée en Indonésie prouve que les premiers humains créaient de l'art symbolique et pensaient de manière créative bien plus tôt et dans plus d'endroits qu'on ne le croyait auparavant.
articles.personality_title_es: La pintura rupestre más antigua del mundo encontrada en Indonesia cambia la historia de la creatividad humana
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos creyeron que los primeros humanos comenzaron a hacer arte y a pensar en símbolos en Europa durante la Edad de Hielo. Las pinturas rupestres son importantes porque muestran cuándo los humanos empezaron a imaginar y compartir ideas de una forma nueva.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores encontraron la pintura rupestre más antigua conocida en la isla indonesia de Sulawesi. Es una plantilla roja de una mano con los dedos en forma de garra. Esta pintura tiene al menos 67,800 años, lo que la hace más antigua que la plantilla de mano más vieja encontrada en España por unos 1,100 años. La pintura se hizo presionando la mano contra la pared de la cueva y rociando pigmento alrededor, luego cambiando la forma de los dedos para que parecieran garras.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que los primeros humanos fueron creativos y usaron símbolos mucho antes de lo que se pensaba, y no solo en Europa. Sugiere que los humanos llegaron a regiones cercanas como Australia y Nueva Guinea mucho antes de lo que algunos expertos creían. La mano con forma de garra también muestra un nuevo nivel de imaginación porque fue un cambio deliberado en la forma de los dedos, algo que no se ve en el arte de los neandertales.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán explorando cuevas en Indonesia y áreas cercanas, donde ya se han encontrado cientos de nuevos sitios de arte rupestre. Estos hallazgos podrían revelar más sobre cómo los primeros humanos usaban el arte para comunicarse y expresar ideas durante miles de años.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La pintura rupestre más antigua encontrada en Indonesia demuestra que los primeros humanos creaban arte simbólico y pensaban creativamente mucho antes y en más lugares de lo que se creía.

articles.personality_title: Ancient Paranthropus fossil found in Ethiopia expands knowledge of early human relatives
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study fossils to learn about early human relatives called hominins. Paranthropus is one group of these early hominins known for strong jaws and teeth, mainly found in East Africa.

**What happened** – Researchers discovered a partial jawbone from Paranthropus that is about 2.6 million years old in the Afar region of Ethiopia. This is a new location for this species, showing they lived in a wider area than previously known.

**Impact** – This fossil helps scientists understand where Paranthropus lived and how they adapted to different environments. It suggests these early humans were more flexible in their diet and habitats, which adds important details to the story of human evolution.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue exploring the Afar region and nearby areas to find more fossils. They will study these remains to learn more about how early hominins lived, survived, and evolved over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A 2.6-million-year-old Paranthropus jawbone found in Ethiopia shows this early human relative lived in more places than scientists thought, enriching our knowledge of human origins.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont découvert une mâchoire partielle de Paranthropus vieille d'environ 2,6 millions d'années dans la région de l'Afar en Éthiopie. C’est un nouvel endroit où cette espèce a été trouvée, montrant qu’elle vivait sur une zone plus étendue que ce qu’on pensait.

**Impact** – Ce fossile aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre où vivait Paranthropus et comment il s’adaptait à différents environnements. Cela suggère que ces premiers humains étaient plus flexibles dans leur alimentation et leur habitat, ce qui ajoute des détails importants à l’histoire de l’évolution humaine.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une mâchoire de Paranthropus vieille de 2,6 millions d’années découverte en Éthiopie montre que ce parent humain ancien vivait dans plus d’endroits qu’on ne le pensait, enrichissant notre connaissance des origines humaines.
articles.personality_title_es: Fósil antiguo de Paranthropus hallado en Etiopía amplía el conocimiento sobre los primeros parientes humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian fósiles para aprender sobre los primeros parientes humanos llamados homínidos. Paranthropus es un grupo de estos homínidos conocido por sus mandíbulas y dientes fuertes, encontrado principalmente en África Oriental.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores descubrieron una mandíbula parcial de Paranthropus de aproximadamente 2,6 millones de años en la región de Afar en Etiopía. Este es un nuevo lugar para esta especie, mostrando que vivían en un área más amplia de lo que se sabía.

articles.title: EU-funded border crossing connecting the Bulgarian town of Rudozem with the Greek town of Xanthi officially opened
articles.summary: The “Rudozem – Xanthi” crossing is included in the Memorandum for enhanced cross-border cooperation between Bulgaria, Greece and Romania
articles.content:
SOFIA/SMOLYAN – The border crossing connecting the Bulgarian town of Rudozem with the Greek town of Xanthi has been officially opened.

The “Rudozem – Xanthi” crossing is financed with funds from the European Union and is a strategic project for connectivity between Bulgaria and Greece – part of the long-term vision for opening new transport corridors through the Rhodope Mountains, the Bulgarian Ministry of Regional Development and Public Works announced. The checkpoint is also included in the Memorandum on enhanced cross-border cooperation between Bulgaria, Greece and Romania, signed in early December in Brussels, which outlines the general framework for the development of strategic infrastructure between the three countries.

The opening of the road section from Dimario to the border with Bulgaria at Rudozem is the final step in a lengthy and very important process for the regions on both the Bulgarian and Greek sides, which completes the connectivity between our countries, commented the Bulgarian caretaker Minister of Foreign Affairs Georg Georgiev at the ceremony. According to him, this will contribute to strengthening economic cooperation, improving transport connectivity and promoting contacts between people on both sides of the border. He emphasized that the implementation of the project creates conditions for the development of tourism, cultural exchange and the regional economy, and in the long term will contribute to the prosperity of both Bulgaria and Greece.

The opening of the “Rudozem – Xanthi” crossing fulfills a 30-year dream of the people on both sides of the border, commented at the ceremony the Bulgarian Deputy Prime Minister and caretaker Minister of Transport and Communications Grozdán Karadzhov.

The Greek Minister of Infrastructure and Transport Christos Dimas, who also attended the opening, stated that the Greek side is committed to repairing the road to Xanthi in order to ensure better communications between the two countries.

At the meeting of the Council of Ministers, the Bulgarian caretaker Prime Minister Rossen Zhelyazkov also emphasized the importance of opening the border crossing for good-neighborly relations, cross-border cooperation, the functioning of the Schengen area and the economic development of the Bulgarian regions.

The newly opened road section from Dimario to the border with Bulgaria at Rudozem is located on the territory of the Hellenic Republic and is part of Vertical Axis 70 to the “Egnatia Odos” motorway. It represents the final infrastructure link on the Greek side to the “Rudozem – Xanthi” border crossing and is of key importance for its full-fledged functioning as a strategic point for regional connectivity, the Bulgarian Ministry of Foreign Affairs pointed out.

The construction of a border checkpoint at Rudozem was agreed in a Bulgarian-Greek agreement in the 1990s, but the opening of the road was postponed for decades. The groundbreaking ceremony for the seventh border checkpoint between Bulgaria and Greece took place in January 2020. On the Bulgarian side, the border checkpoint was completed in 2021, and on the Greek side – by the end of 2024, but the opening was postponed several times due to the construction of adjacent infrastructure on Greek territory, the Bulgarian “Border Police” reported. (20–21.01.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports the official opening of a new EU-funded border crossing between Bulgaria and Greece, a significant infrastructure project that enhances regional connectivity, economic cooperation, tourism, and cultural exchange. This development has broad positive impacts on the general public in both countries and fulfills a long-standing regional goal, supported by detailed context and statements from officials.

articles.title: Ape-like hominin Paranthropus was more adaptable than we thought
articles.summary: A fossil discovery in northern Ethiopia expands the known range of Paranthropus, a genus of strong-jawed hominins that lived around 2 million years ago, and suggests they lived in a range of habitats
articles.content:
A fossil discovery in northern Ethiopia expands the known range of Paranthropus, a genus of strong-jawed hominins that lived around 2 million years ago, and suggests they lived in a range of habitats

Illustration of Paranthropus hominins, which lived between 2.7 and 1.4 million years ago JOHN BAVARO FINE ART/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

For the first time, the remains of ancient humans called Paranthropus have been found in the remote Afar region of Ethiopia. The discovery dramatically expands the area over which Paranthropus roamed, and suggests they lived in a wide range of ecosystems.

Paranthropus remains are known from eastern and southern Africa, between 2.7 and 1.4 million years ago. They are thought to be closely related to Homo, the group that includes modern humans and Neanderthals. They may have evolved from earlier hominins called Australopithecus.

Zeresenay Alemseged at the University of Chicago in Illinois and his colleagues have been excavating a site called Mille-Logya, in the Afar depression in north-east Ethiopia, since 2012. The Afar is a treasure trove of hominin remains, including many Homo and Australopithecus remains. “Paranthropus had been eluding us,” he says. “We had pretty much concluded that it had never made it that far north.”

On 19 January 2019, Alemseged’s local assistant brought him a part of a lower jawbone, with no teeth. “The first thing that struck me was its size,” says Alemseged. That same day, the team also found the crown of a left lower molar tooth.

A CT scan confirmed telltale Paranthropus traits: not just the size of the jawbone but the proportion of width to height, and the complexity of the tooth roots hidden inside the jaw. The team couldn’t tell which of the three recognised species of Paranthropus the bones belong to, but based on the location it is likely to be Paranthropus aethiopicus or Paranthropus boisei.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

The jawbone is about 2.6 million years old, the team says, based on multiple dating methods. That makes it one of the oldest Paranthropus known.

“There’s no question that it’s Paranthropus,” says Carrie Mongle at Stony Brook University, New York, who wasn’t involved in the research. “I don’t think there’s any question about the date.”

The fragments of the Paranthropus mandible after being assembled in the field Alemseged Research Group/University of Chicago

Previously, the northernmost Paranthropus specimen was a skull from Konso in southern Ethiopia. The new specimen is over 1000 kilometres further north.

“The main point is that it expands the geographic range of Paranthropus,” says Mongle.

For Alemseged, the new specimen is also evidence of greater versatility. Paranthropus’s large jaws and teeth have long been interpreted as evidence of a tough, chewy diet. While we don’t yet know what the Mille-Logya Paranthropus ate, the area seems to have been relatively open, whereas other early specimens of Paranthropus were found in wooded areas.

“Yes, they were specialised,” says Alemseged, “[but] I think we might have inflated our understanding of that specialisation.” Their specialised bodies don’t seem to have stopped them living in both wooded and grassy areas. “Different Paranthropus populations were able to exploit different habitats based on where they lived, like Homo did, like Australopithecus did.”

Mongle says there was already evidence of Paranthropus succeeding in new environments, because they adapted to the expansion of grasslands across east Africa, opting to eat more grasses. The new Mille-Logya specimen adds to the evidence of their versatility.

In recent years, evidence has emerged that Paranthropus could use, and perhaps also make, simple stone tools. For instance, stone tools described in 2023 from Kenya were found associated with Paranthropus teeth and no other hominin remains. In 2025, Mongle helped describe the first Paranthropus hand, which proved to be highly dextrous.

That makes sense, says Alemseged, because there is growing evidence that Australopithecus could make and use tools, and they existed before Paranthropus. Tool use may well go back to the ancestor we share with chimpanzees, he says.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of Paranthropus fossils in a new geographic area significantly expands scientific understanding of early human relatives' adaptability and habitat range, providing meaningful insights into human evolution that inspire curiosity and hope about our origins.
articles.personality_title: Ancient Paranthropus fossils found far north in Ethiopia, showing they adapted to many environments
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Paranthropus were early human relatives with strong jaws who lived about 2 million years ago. Until now, their fossils were found mostly in eastern and southern Africa. They are thought to be close relatives of modern humans and Neanderthals.

**What happened** – In 2019, researchers discovered parts of a Paranthropus jawbone and tooth in northern Ethiopia’s Afar region, over 1,000 kilometers farther north than any previous find. The fossils are about 2.6 million years old. This discovery came from a site called Mille-Logya, where scientists have been digging since 2012.

**Impact** – This find shows Paranthropus lived in more places than previously known. It also suggests they could live in different habitats, including open grassy areas, not just wooded ones. This challenges the idea that they were only specialized for one type of environment. It helps us understand that early human relatives were more flexible and adaptable than we thought.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will keep studying the Mille-Logya site to find more fossils and learn what Paranthropus ate and how they lived. They will also explore how tool use and other skills might have helped them survive in varied environments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The discovery of Paranthropus fossils far north in Ethiopia reveals they lived in diverse habitats, showing early human relatives were more adaptable than once believed.
